title: PHP and Wordpress version disclosure

profile.name: Ian Dunn
profile.about: I'm a WordPress developer who maintains several small open source projects.

vulnerability_information:
**Vulnerable File**
google-authenticator-per-user-prompt/views/requirements-error.php

**Description**
That file discloses the PHP version and Wordpress version to the world.Which is not a bug actually,but these information can be helpful to demonstrate further devastating bugs.

**Suggestion**
I saw that you rejected many path disclosure reports cause those are not in your hand.It depends upon server settings,how that will handle error messages.But this case is different.Its not actually an error message.And cant be mitigated by switching off error display.
I suggest you to keep such actions so that unauthorized users could not use this file directly.
vulnerability_information_html:
Vulnerable File
google-authenticator-per-user-prompt/views/requirements-error.php

Description
That file discloses the PHP version and Wordpress version to the world.Which is not a bug actually,but these information can be helpful to demonstrate further devastating bugs.

Suggestion
I saw that you rejected many path disclosure reports cause those are not in your hand.It depends upon server settings,how that will handle error messages.But this case is different.Its not actually an error message.And cant be mitigated by switching off error display.
I suggest you to keep such actions so that unauthorized users could not use this file directly.

activities.message:
my suggestion will be to use 
```php
 <?php login_header(); ?>
```
On the starting of this file.
activities.markdown_message:
my suggestion will be to use 

 <?php login_header(); ?>

On the starting of this file.

activities.message:
Hi siddiki, thanks for the report, but I don't consider the PHP or WordPress versions to be secrets. The WordPress version can easily be determined by viewing the cachebuster parameters on CSS files in the source of `wp-login.php`, and the PHP version can often be obtained from `curl -I http://example.org`.

It's possible the version could be used to determine if a release with known vulnerabilities was installed, but the real problem there is that the admin hasn't upgraded. Hiding it is just security-through-obscurity.
activities.markdown_message:
Hi siddiki, thanks for the report, but I don't consider the PHP or WordPress versions to be secrets. The WordPress version can easily be determined by viewing the cachebuster parameters on CSS files in the source of wp-login.php, and the PHP version can often be obtained from curl -I http://example.org.

It's possible the version could be used to determine if a release with known vulnerabilities was installed, but the real problem there is that the admin hasn't upgraded. Hiding it is just security-through-obscurity.
